title: Survey of End-to-End Multi-Speaker Automatic Speech Recognition for Monaural Audio
author: Xinlu He (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), Jacob Whitehill (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), ...
relevance_why: This paper provides a comprehensive review of end-to-end multi-speaker automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems, focusing on architectures that are crucial for Haohe Liu's research in audio processing.
background: Multi-speaker automatic speech recognition involves transcribing audio that contains overlapping speech from multiple speakers, aiming to identify who is speaking what.
contribution: This survey introduces a systematic taxonomy of end-to-end neural approaches for multi-speaker ASR, highlighting various architectural paradigms and improvements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing literature reviews on ASR primarily focus on single-speaker systems, lacking comprehensive analysis for multi-speaker ASR.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work consolidates recent research advancements, analyzes architectural paradigms, and compares methods across standard benchmarks.

key_innovation: Offers a structured review and comparison of distinct E2E architectures for multi-speaker ASR, specifically differentiating between Single-Input Multiple-Output and Single-Input Single-Output frameworks.
real_world_impact: The findings and insights from this survey can inform the development of more accurate and robust ASR systems that are applicable in real-world environments like meetings and group discussions.
limitations: The survey does not delve into hyperparameter tuning for different architectures or provide detailed performance metrics across all existing methods.

new_terms.end-to-end (E2E): **End-to-End (E2E)** systems directly map raw audio inputs to transcriptions without intermediate processing steps.
new_terms.Permutation Invariant Training (PIT): **Permutation Invariant Training (PIT)** is a training approach that addresses the output label ambiguity in multi-speaker scenarios by evaluating all possible permutations of outputs.
